questions.text: Thiopentone is used for the induction of a 30-year-old patient posted for hernia repair. The other properties of Thiopentone given in the following are true except
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Thiopentone (thiopental sodium) is a barbiturate commonly used for the induction of anesthesia. It has several distinct properties:
    • It acts as a CNS depressant and has anti-convulsant properties, making it useful in status epilepticus.
    • Known historically as a "truth serum" due to its sedative effects that reduce inhibitions.
    • Has a distinctive garlicky or onion-like odour due to sulfur-containing metabolites.
  • However, green discoloration of urine is not associated with thiopentone; it is classically seen with propofol metabolism, making Option C incorrect.

Key Takeaways:

  • Thiopentone does not cause green urine—this is a feature of propofol.
  • Has anti-convulsant activity and a garlicky smell. (Options B & D ruled out)
  • Historically referred to as "truth serum". (Option A ruled out)

choices.text: Should be discarded in 6 hours after opening

questions.text: Identify the given agent. What is not true about the agent?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • The image shows Propofol, a widely used intravenous induction agent formulated as a 1% oil-in-water emulsion.
  • The emulsion contains soybean oil, egg lecithin (a phospholipid from egg yolk), and glycerol.
  • Although it contains egg lecithin, studies show that patients with egg allergy (typically to egg white/albumin)can safely receive propofol. Therefore, it is not strictly contraindicated in egg allergy, making Option B incorrect.
  • Due to its emulsion base, propofol supports bacterial growth and must be discarded within 6 hours of opening to avoid contamination.
  • It does indeed contain glycerol as a stabilizer and is formulated as an oil-in-water emulsion.

Key Takeaways:

  • Propofol is not contraindicated in egg allergy in most cases.
  • Must be discarded within 6 hours of opening. (Option A ruled out)
  • Contains glycerol and is an oil-in-water emulsion. (Option C & D ruled out)

questions.text: Which of the following is propofol not used in?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Propofol is contraindicated or used with extreme caution in shock due to its potent vasodilatory and myocardial depressant effects, which can cause severe hypotension and compromise perfusion in an already unstable patient.
  • It is commonly used in daycare surgeries because of its rapid onset and quick recovery profile.
  • Propofol is safe in porphyria, as it does not induce enzymes involved in heme synthesis, unlike barbiturates.
  • In neurosurgery, it is favored due to its ability to lower intracranial pressure (ICP) and cerebral metabolic rate.

Key Takeaways:

  • Propofol is avoided in shock due to the risk of worsening hypotension.
  • Suitable for daycare, neurosurgery, and porphyria (Option A, B & D ruled out)
  • Offers rapid onset, short duration, and neuroprotective effects.

questions.text: Among the given intravenous induction agents, which is an imidazole compound?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Both Etomidate and Midazolam are structurally classified as imidazole compounds.
  • Etomidate is an imidazole-derived sedative-hypnotic used for induction, known for its cardiovascular stability and adrenal suppression.
  • Midazolam, though primarily known as a benzodiazepine, is also chemically derived from the imidazole ring, which contributes to its water solubility at acidic pH and lipophilicity at physiological pH.
  • Propofol, in contrast, is a phenol derivative, not an imidazole. (Option B ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • Etomidate and Midazolam are both imidazole derivatives.
  • Propofol is a phenol, not related to imidazole chemistry.
  • Chemical structure impacts solubility and pharmacokinetics.

questions.text: Identify the given agent. Why is it contraindicated for sedation in the intensive care unit?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The agent shown is Etomidate, a short-acting IV anesthetic induction agent.
  • It is contraindicated for prolonged sedation in the ICU due to its inhibition of 11β-hydroxylase, an enzyme critical for cortisol and aldosterone synthesis.
  • Even a single dose can cause transient adrenal suppression, and prolonged infusions may lead to life-threatening adrenal insufficiency, especially in critically ill or septic patients.
  • While nausea and vomiting and prolonged recovery are recognized side effects, they are not reasons for ICU contraindication. (Options B and C ruled out)
  • Etomidate is not known to promote bacterial growth via its formulation. (Option D ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • Etomidate inhibits adrenal steroid synthesis, making it unsuitable for long-term sedation in ICUs.
  • Best reserved for single-dose induction in hemodynamically unstable patients.
  • Monitor for hypocortisolism in ICU settings if used.

questions.text: Identify the given agent. What is true about the agent being the first choice for
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The image displays Ketamine Hydrochloride, a dissociative anesthetic with analgesic, amnesic, and sympathomimetic properties, making it uniquely suitable for multiple acute care settings.
  • It is the first-choice agent in:
    • Field anesthesia (e.g., trauma, battlefield) is due to its hemodynamic stability and preservation of airway reflexes.
    • Acute shock, as ketamine increases heart rate and blood pressure, supporting cardiovascular function.
    • Asthma, because it causes bronchodilation, making it safe for airway-compromised patients.

Key Takeaways:

  • Ketamine is ideal for unstable patients, especially in emergency, trauma, or respiratory distress.
  • It is safe and effective in hypovolemia, asthma, and prehospital care.
  • Its unique profile combines analgesia, sedation, and cardiovascular support.

questions.text: Dexmedetomidine is not an induction agent, but is used as an adjuvant for its following properties.
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Dexmedetomidine is a highly selective alpha-2 adrenergic agonist that is not used for the induction of anesthesia but is widely used as an adjuvant due to its sympatholytic, analgesic, and sedative properties
  • It provides cooperative sedation, useful in ICU and procedural sedation, and contributes to analgesia by reducing opioid requirements.
  • Its sympatholytic effect leads to decreased norepinephrine release, causing bradycardia and hypotension, beneficial in selected settings.

Key Takeaways:

  • Dexmedetomidine is a sedative, analgesic, and sympatholytic adjuvant.
  • Not used for induction, but valuable for ICU sedation and opioid-sparing effects.
  • Supports hemodynamic stability in perioperative care.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man undergoing an inguinal hernia repair is induced with propofol. Which of the following is most likely to be observed?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Propofol is a potent respiratory depressant and frequently causes apnea following induction, especially when administered rapidly or in higher doses.
  • This effect is due to central respiratory depression, making assisted ventilation often necessary until spontaneous breathing resumes.
  • Apnea is a well-documented and expected response during induction with propofol.

Explanation of other options:
Hyperthermia (Option A): Not associated with propofol, more characteristic of malignant hyperthermia, seen with certain inhalational agents or succinylcholine.

Hypertension (Option B): Propofol typically causes hypotension due to vasodilation and myocardial depression.

Prolonged sedation (Option D): Propofol has a rapid onset and short duration; sedation is not usually prolonged unless infused continuously.

Key Takeaways:

  • Apnea is a common and expected side effect of propofol induction
  • Monitor for respiratory depression and be ready to provide ventilatory support
  • Propofol typically causes hypotension, not hypertension

questions.text: A patient who was under sedative infusion in the intensive care unit developed greenish urine and green discoloration of hair. Which sedative agent has been used in this patient
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Propofol metabolism produces phenolic metabolites, which can cause green discoloration of urine, and rarely, hair with prolonged infusions.
  • This effect is benign, dose-dependent, and more commonly seen with prolonged ICU sedation.
  • It results from the conjugation and excretion of these metabolites in urine and other secretions.

Explanation of other options:
Thiopentone sodium (Option A): Not known to cause discoloration of urine or hair.

Midazolam (Option B): A benzodiazepine with no associated pigmentary side effects.

Fentanyl (Option D): An opioid that does not affect urine or hair color.

Key Takeaways:

  • Propofol can cause green urine and hair due to phenolic metabolites
  • This is benign and occurs with prolonged use
  • Other common sedatives, like midazolam or fentanyl, do not cause this effect

questions.text: A patient has been induced with a bolus dose of propofol for general anesthesia. After how long is the patient expected to wake up from this single bolus dose of propofol?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Propofol is a rapid-onset, short-acting intravenous anesthetic with high lipid solubility.
  • After a single bolus, it is rapidly redistributed from the brain to peripheral tissues, leading to emergence from anesthesia typically within 8–10 minutes.
  • The wake-up time is governed by redistribution, not metabolism, after a single bolus dose.

questions.text: A 48-year-old female is being induced for general anesthesia with propofol. Which of the following effects is least expected with the induction?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

Propofol commonly causes hypotension, pain on injection, and apnea, primarily due to vasodilation, negative inotropic effects, and central respiratory depression. However, tachycardia is not typically expected with propofol; in fact, it often causes bradycardia or no change in heart rate due to sympatholytic action.

Hypotension is a well-known and frequent side effect resulting from peripheral vasodilation and reduced preload and afterload (Option A ruled out).

Pain on injection is a very common issue with IV propofol, especially when injected into smaller veins, and occurs due to irritation of the venous endothelium (Option C ruled out).

Apnea is frequently observed, especially during induction, due to direct depression of the respiratory centers in the brainstem (Option D ruled out).

Key Takeaways:

  • Tachycardia is uncommon with propofol induction
  • Hypotension, injection pain, and apnea are well-documented side effects
  • Propofol has vasodilatory and depressant effects

questions.text: A 30-year-old male weighing 130 kg is posted for a sleeve gastrectomy bariatric surgery. Which of the following drugs during induction must be given according to the total body weight of the patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Propofol is lipophilic and distributes extensively into adipose tissue, especially in obese patients.
  • During induction, the initial dose of propofol should be based on total body weight (TBW) to achieve adequate plasma levels and rapid onset.
  • Maintenance dosing, however, is adjusted to lean body weight to avoid overdose.

Explanation of other options:
Thiopentone sodium (Option A): The Induction dose is calculated based on lean body weight due to limited fat solubility and risk of accumulation.

Fentanyl (Option C): Dosed based on lean body weight to minimize the risk of prolonged respiratory depression.

Rocuronium (Option D): Dosed according to ideal body weight to avoid excessive neuromuscular blockade.

Key Takeaways:

  • The propofol induction dose is based on total body weight in obesity
  • Other agents like thiopentone, fentanyl, and rocuronium use lean or ideal body weight
  • Tailoring drug dosing in obesity is essential to balance efficacy and safety

questions.text: What is the induction agent of choice for a child with flame burns undergoing burn dressing under general anesthesia?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Ketamine is the induction agent of choice in burn patients, especially in children, due to its cardiovascular stability and analgesic properties.
  • It maintains spontaneous respiration, supports hemodynamics, and provides profound analgesia, which is particularly useful during painful procedures like burn dressing.
  • Additionally, ketamine does not significantly depress the airway reflexes or respiratory drive.

Explanation of other options:
Propofol (Option A): Can cause hypotension due to vasodilation; not ideal in burn patients with potential fluid loss and instability.

Thiopentone sodium (Option B): Causes cardiovascular depression; lacks analgesic properties, not preferred for dressing changes.

Etomidate (Option C): Provides stable hemodynamics but lacks analgesic effects and can cause adrenal suppression with repeated use.

Key Takeaways:

  • Ketamine is ideal for burn dressing due to analgesia, hemodynamic stability, and preservation of respiration.
  • Avoid agents like Propofol or Thiopentone in unstable burn patients
  • Etomidate is hemodynamically stable but lacks pain control

questions.text: A 30-year-old female develops postoperative delirium with hallucinations and disorientation after emergence from anesthesia. Which anesthetic agent is most likely responsible for these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Ketamine is known to cause emergence delirium, especially in young adults and females, characterized by hallucinations, vivid dreams, and disorientation
  • These effects are attributed to its action as an NMDA receptor antagonist and its dissociative anesthetic
  • Premedication with benzodiazepines may reduce the incidence, but does not eliminate the risk.

Explanation of other options:
Propofol (Option B): Has antiemetic and sedative effects; does not cause emergence delirium.

Thiopentone sodium (Option C): May cause postoperative drowsiness, but not typically associated with delirium.

Etomidate (Option D): Minimal CNS side effects; more commonly associated with myoclonus and adrenal suppression.

Key Takeaways:

  • Ketamine is associated with emergence delirium, especially in young females.
  • Caused by NMDA receptor antagonism and dissociative effects
  • Premedication with benzodiazepines can help reduce symptoms

questions.text: What cardiovascular effect is most likely to occur if ketamine is administered to an ICU patient in a catecholamine-depleted state?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Ketamine’s cardiovascular effects (increased heart rate, BP, and cardiac output) are due to indirect sympathetic stimulation by releasing endogenous catecholamines.
  • In a catecholamine-depleted state (e.g., septic or prolonged shock), these stores are exhausted, so ketamine’s direct myocardial depressant effect becomes unmasked.
  • This leads to decreased cardiac output and potential cardiovascular collapse in such patients.

Explanation of other options:
Tachycardia (Option A): Expected in normal patients due to sympathomimetic action, but not seen in catecholamine depletion.

Increase in blood pressure (Option B): Typically occurs with ketamine, but not when endogenous catecholamines are depleted.

Increased cardiac output (Option D): Only occurs when sympathetic stores are intact; not in depleted states.

Key Takeaways:

  • Ketamine depresses myocardial function directly in catecholamine-depleted states.
  • Its usual sympathomimetic effects are dependent on endogenous catecholamine.s
  • Always assess hemodynamic reserve before using ketamine in ICU patients.

questions.text: A patient comes to the operating room with a history of polytrauma and a blood pressure of 80/60 mm Hg. Which of the following will be the induction agent of choice?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Ketamine is the induction agent of choice in hemodynamically unstable patients due to its sympathomimetic properties.
  • It increases heart rate, cardiac output, and blood pressure by stimulating the sympathetic nervous system, making it ideal for hypotensive trauma
  • Unlike other agents that may depress myocardial function, ketamine supports circulatory stability.

Explanation of other options:
Propofol (Option B): Causes vasodilation and myocardial depression, leading to significant hypotension; contraindicated in shock.

Thiopentone (Option C): Causes vasodilation and myocardial depression; not preferred in unstable patients.

Midazolam (Option D): Has cardiodepressant effects and may exacerbate hypotension in trauma patients.

Key Takeaways:

  • Ketamine is preferred in trauma with hypotension
  • Avoid Propofol, Thiopentone, and Midazolam in shock
  • Use agents with sympathomimetic effects in hemodynamic instability

questions.text: A 38-year-old male with a history of a road traffic accident was found to have a subdural hematoma on MRI brain with significant midline shift. He was scheduled for an emergency evacuation of the hematoma by a craniotomy. Which induction agent should be avoided for this patient, given the intracranial bleed?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Ketamine increases cerebral blood flow (CBF), intracranial pressure (ICP), and cerebral metabolic rate, which can exacerbate intracranial hypertension and worsen outcomes in patients with intracranial bleeding or mass effect.
  • In a patient with subdural hematoma and midline shift, it is critical to avoid agents that increase ICP.
  • Therefore, ketamine is contraindicated in such scenarios due to its ICP-raising 

Explanation of other options:

Thiopentone sodium (Option A): Reduces ICP, CBF, and CMRO2 (Cerebral Metabolic Rate of Oxygen); often used in neuroanesthesia.

Propofol (Option B): Decreases CBF, ICP, and CMRO2; suitable for patients with raised ICP.

Etomidate (Option D): Has minimal effects on CBF and ICP; considered safe in neuroanesthesia.

Key Takeaways:

  • Ketamine should be avoided in raised ICP or intracranial bleed
  • Thiopentone, Propofol, and Etomidate are safe induction agents for neuro cases
  • Avoid agents that increase CBF and ICP in neurosurgical emergencies

questions.text: Which of the following induction agents is associated with the Robinhood phenomenon?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • The Robinhood phenomenon (reverse cerebral steal) occurs when vasoconstriction in normally perfused cerebral areas redirects blood flow to ischemic regions where vessels are already maximally dilated.
  • Thiopentone sodium decreases cerebral metabolic rate (CMRO2) and intracranial pressure (ICP).
  • It induces cerebral vasoconstriction, which favors redistribution of blood toward ischemic tissue, producing the reverse steal effect.

Explanation of other options:

Ketamine (Option A): Causes cerebral vasodilation and increases CBF and ICP, which can worsen cerebral ischemia.

Propofol (Option B): Causes global reduction in CBF and CMRO2, but is not specifically associated with the reverse steal phenomenon.

Etomidate (Option C): Minimally affects CBF and ICP, not associated with Robinhood phenomenon.

Key Takeaways:

  • Thiopentone causes cerebral vasoconstriction and may lead to reverse steal
  • Ketamine increases CBF and ICP
  • The Robinhood phenomenon benefits ischemic brain areas

choices.text: Like all general anesthetic agents, ketamine has strong activity at the GABA-A receptor.
NMDA receptor antagonism is the main mechanism of the ketamine effect
Ketamine blocks the release of glutamate in the CNS
Ketamine blocks activity at muscarinic receptors in the central nervous system

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding ketamine is false?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Ketamine does not primarily act on the GABA-A receptor, which differentiates it from most other general anesthetic agents. This statement is false, making Option A the correct answer.
  • NMDA receptor antagonism is the main mechanism through which ketamine exerts its anesthetic and analgesic effects (Option B ruled out).
  • Ketamine also blocks the release of glutamate in the CNS, which contributes to its analgesic and dissociative properties (Option C ruled out).
  • It has additional central anticholinergic activity, particularly at muscarinic receptors, which supports its role in bronchodilation and psychotropic effects (Option D ruled out).

Key Takeaways:

  • Ketamine does not significantly act on GABA-A receptors
  • It functions via NMDA receptor antagonism and reduces glutamate activity
  • Exhibits anticholinergic and sympathomimetic effects

questions.text: A patient during induction of anesthesia complains of a garlicky taste. Which induction agent is known to cause this effect?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Thiopentone sodium is known to cause a transient garlicky or onion-like taste during intravenous induction.
  • This effect is thought to be due to the drug’s sulfur-containing structure and rapid access to the olfactory cortex, where it stimulates smell and taste sensations.
  • Although not harmful, this side effect can be disconcerting if unexpected.

Explanation of other options:
Propofol (Option B): Commonly causes pain on injection and hypotension, but it is not associated with taste disturbances.

Ketamine (Option C): Known for dissociative anesthesia, hallucinations, and sympathomimetic effects, but does not alter taste perception.

Etomidate (Option D): Associated with myoclonus and adrenocortical suppression, but not known to produce sensory alterations like taste changes.

Key Takeaways:

  • Garlicky taste on induction is a unique feature of thiopentone sodium
  • Caused by its sulfur-based chemistry and CNS penetration
  • Not observed with propofol, ketamine, or etomidate

questions.text: You are asked to anaesthetize a 60-year-old lady suffering from severe refractory depression for electro-convulsive therapy. Which of the following induction agents would enable the greatest seizure quality?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Etomidate is preferred for ECT because it prolongs seizure duration due to its minimal anticonvulsant activity.
  • It provides cardiovascular stability, which is important for elderly or compromised patients.
  • Longer and better-quality seizures correlate with improved therapeutic outcomes in ECT.

Explanation of other options:
Propofol (Option A): Has significant anticonvulsant properties and shortens seizure duration, reducing the effectiveness of ECT.

Thiopentone (Option C): A barbiturate with strong anticonvulsant effects that can suppress seizure activity.

Ketamine (Option D): Has pro-convulsant potential but is avoided due to prolonged emergence and psychomimetic effects.

Key Takeaways:

  • Etomidate is the induction agent of choice for maximizing seizure quality in ECT.
  • Propofol and thiopentone suppress seizures and are less effective.
  • Ketamine has limited use due to undesirable side effects.

questions.text:
Regarding ketamine, mark true (T) or false (F).
1. Stimulation of the sympathetic nervous system
2. Decreased myocardial oxygen requirements
3. Bronchodilatation
4. Dissociation between the thalamocortical and limbic systems
5. Less emetogenic than other induction agents
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Ketamine is a unique intravenous anesthetic that produces dissociative anesthesia along with profound sympathetic stimulation and bronchodilation. It is commonly used in trauma, asthmatic patients, and settings with limited cardiovascular reserve.
  • Statement 1 is true – Ketamine causes stimulation of the sympathetic nervous system by promoting the release of endogenous catecholamines, resulting in increased heart rate, blood pressure, and cardiac output. This makes it useful in hypotensive states or shock.
  • Statement 2 is false – Ketamine increases myocardial oxygen requirements due to its positive chronotropic and inotropic effects, contrary to the suggestion of reduced demand. It is not ideal for patients with ischemic heart disease.
  • Statement 3 is true – Ketamine causes bronchodilatation through direct smooth muscle relaxation and inhibition of vagal pathways, making it the preferred induction agent in asthmatics or patients with reactive airways.
  • Statement 4 is true – Ketamine induces dissociative anesthesia by causing a functional disconnection between the thalamocortical and limbic systems, resulting in profound analgesia and amnesia while preserving airway reflexes and spontaneous respiration.
  • Statement 5 is false – Ketamine is more emetogenic than agents like propofol and is associated with a higher risk of postoperative nausea and vomiting, so antiemetic prophylaxis may be considered.

Key Takeaways:

  • Ketamine stimulates the sympathetic system and causes bronchodilation.
  • It increases myocardial oxygen consumption and is more emetogenic than some agents.
  • Produces dissociative anesthesia via thalamocortical-limbic disconnection.

questions.text: A 20-year-old college basketball player with a history of prolonged QT syndrome presents for an inguinal hernia repair. Which of the following agents would be least likely to further lengthen the QT interval?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

Propofol is the preferred anesthetic agent in patients with prolonged QT syndrome because it has minimal to no effect on cardiac repolarization or QT interval, making it least likely to exacerbate the condition.

Explanation of other options:
Ondansetron (Option A): Commonly associated with QT prolongation, especially in high doses; carries an FDA warning for this risk.

Metoclopramide (Option B): Has been implicated in QT interval prolongation and is not ideal for patients with arrhythmia susceptibility.

Succinylcholine (Option C): Can cause autonomic stimulation and potassium shifts, both of which may prolong QT and trigger arrhythmias.

Key Takeaways:

  • Propofol is QT-neutral and preferred in long QT syndrome.
  • Avoid QT-prolonging agents like ondansetron, metoclopramide, and succinylcholine in susceptible patients.

questions.text: A patient has been administered etomidate for the induction of anesthesia. Which of the following effects is not attributable to etomidate anesthesia?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Etomidate is known for its hemodynamic stability and minimal respiratory depression, making it especially useful in patients with cardiovascular compromise. However, emergence delirium is not a known side effect of etomidate; this is more characteristic of ketamine due to its dissociative properties.

Myoclonus is a common effect during induction with etomidate, resulting from subcortical disinhibition and often observed even in the absence of seizure activity (Option B ruled out).

Adrenocortical suppression occurs due to inhibition of 11β-hydroxylase, impairing cortisol and aldosterone synthesis, and can happen even after a single dose, especially relevant in septic or critically ill patients (Option C ruled out).

Post-operative nausea and vomiting (PONV) is relatively more common with etomidate compared to other induction agents, sometimes warranting antiemetic prophylaxis in at-risk patients (Option D ruled out).

Key Takeaways:

  • Etomidate does not cause emergence delirium, a feature of ketamine.
  • Known effects: myoclonus, PONV, and adrenocortical suppression.
  • Often used when hemodynamic stability is a priority.

questions.text: In a patient with recurrent seizures, which of the following may help in mapping a seizure focus under general anesthesia by enhancing the EEG activity or inducing the seizure?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Etomidate has a unique ability to enhance EEG activity and may even induce seizures, making it useful in epilepsy surgery to help localize seizure foci.
  • This property is harnessed during intraoperative electrocorticography to optimize the identification of epileptogenic zones.

Explanation of other options:
Thiopental (Option A): A barbiturate with potent anticonvulsant properties; it suppresses EEG activity and would obscure seizure mapping.

Diazepam (Option C): A benzodiazepine, it strongly inhibits seizures and is used for seizure termination, not mapping.

Isoflurane (Option D): A volatile agent that suppresses cortical activity, making it unsuitable for EEG-based seizure focus mapping.

Key Takeaways:

  • Etomidate enhances EEG activity and may provoke seizure activity, aiding in seizure focus localization.
  • Thiopental, diazepam, and isoflurane suppress seizure activity and are not suitable for this purpose.
  • Etomidate’s pro-convulsant potential is clinically valuable in epilepsy surgery.

questions.text: Which of the following intravenous anaesthetics can be used to reduce postoperative pain?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Ketamine is unique among IV anesthetics for its potent NMDA receptor antagonism, which plays a key role in preventing central sensitization and reducing postoperative pain.
  • Even at sub-anesthetic doses, ketamine has analgesic properties that contribute to opioid-sparing effects

Explanation of other options:
Etomidate (Option A): Has no intrinsic analgesic effects and is primarily used for hemodynamic stability during induction.

Propofol (Option B): Provides sedation and hypnosis, but lacks meaningful analgesic properties and does not reduce postoperative pain.

Thiopentone (Option D): A barbiturate used for induction; it lacks analgesic action and can cause postoperative hyperalgesia in some cases.

Key Takeaways:

  • Ketamine is the only IV anesthetic with clinically useful postoperative analgesic effects.
  • It acts via NMDA receptor antagonism, preventing central sensitization.
  • Other agents like etomidate, propofol, and thiopentone have no analgesic benefit.

choices.text: Less incidence of hypotension and apnoea

questions.text: Regarding Fospropofol, which of the following statements is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Fospropofol is a water-soluble prodrug of propofol, converted into active propofol by alkaline phosphatase in the body. This delayed enzymatic conversion makes it slower in onset compared to directly administered propofol.
  • It causes less pain on injection because it lacks the lipid emulsion component of standard propofol, which irritates veins (Option C ruled out).
  • It is associated with less hypotension and apnea than propofol, as the active compound is released gradually (Option A ruled out).
  • The description of fospropofol as a water-soluble prodrug of propofol is accurate and pharmacologically well established (Option B ruled out).

questions.text: Which of the following Intravenous induction agents is associated with abuse liability?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Propofol is associated with abuse liability, especially among healthcare professionals, due to its ability to induce rapid-onset euphoria, sedation, and disinhibition.
  • Although it lacks traditional addictive withdrawal symptoms, repeated use can lead to psychological dependence.
  • Its rapid onset and offset, combined with pleasant subjective effects, make it a target for abuse.

Explanation of other options:
Etomidate (Option B): Not associated with abuse. It lacks euphoric or reinforcing effects.

Methohexital (Option C): While it has a rapid onset, it does not produce euphoria or reinforcing effects leading to abuse.

Thiopentone (Option D): Has sedative-hypnotic effects but is rarely abused due to slower recovery and unpleasant side effects.

Key Takeaways:

  • Propofol is the only induction agent among the options with known abuse potential.
  • Abuse is primarily seen in medical professionals due to easy access.
  • Other agents lack reinforcing or euphoric effects.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs can trigger malignant hyperthermia?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Halothane is a volatile anesthetic that can precipitate malignant hyperthermia (MH) by causing uncontrolled calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum (Option A).
  • Succinylcholine is a depolarizing neuromuscular blocker that is a classic MH trigger, especially in genetically predisposed individuals (Option B).
  • Enflurane is another inhalational anesthetic with the potential to trigger MH through its effects on calcium handling in skeletal muscle (Option C).

Key Takeaways:

  • All three agents listed are recognized MH triggers.
  • MH is associated with RYR1 mutations, muscle rigidity, and hyperthermia.
  • Managed with dantrolene and supportive care.

questions.text: Which of the following agents is associated with a rise in intraocular pressure?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Ketamine causes an increase in intraocular pressure (IOP) due to its sympathomimetic effects, increased muscle tone, and systemic hypertension, making it unsuitable for ophthalmic procedures.
  • Thiopentone decreases IOP through central nervous system depression and reduced aqueous humor production (Option A ruled out).
  • Desflurane has minimal or no significant effect on IOP and is not contraindicated in ocular surgery (Option B ruled out).
  • Propofol is known to lower IOP by causing systemic vasodilation and reducing ocular blood flow (Option C ruled out).

Key Takeaways:

  • Ketamine increases IOP and should be avoided in eye surgeries.
  • Thiopentone and propofol decrease IOP; desflurane is IOP-neutral.
  • Choice of induction agent affects ocular pressure and surgical outcomes.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male underwent surgery under general anesthesia. During recovery, he experienced hallucinations and vivid dreams. These symptoms are likely related to the intravenous anesthetic agent used for induction. Which of the following could have prevented this reaction?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • The symptoms of hallucinations and vivid dreams during recovery are typical of ketamine-induced emergence reactions. These are due to its action as a dissociative anesthetic.
  • Administering midazolam, a benzodiazepine, before ketamine induction can significantly reduce the incidence of these emergence phenomena by providing anxiolysis, amnesia, and sedation.

Explanation of other options:

Propofol (Option A): Is not used to prevent ketamine-induced dreams, but is an alternative induction agent.

Atropine (Option C): Is used to counteract bradycardia or excessive secretions and has no role in preventing emergence delirium.

Ketamine (Option D): Is the causative agent here, not the preventive one.

Key Takeaways:

  • Midazolam premedication reduces ketamine-related emergence reactions.
  • Ketamine causes vivid dreams and hallucinations during emergence.
  • Propofol and atropine do not prevent emergence delirium.

questions.text: Which of the following is the primary site of action of ketamine?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Ketamine primarily acts on the thalamocortical projection system by blocking NMDA receptors, leading to a dissociative state where sensory input is disconnected from perception. This disrupts the connection between the limbic system and neocortex, producing analgesia, amnesia, and catalepsy.

Explanation of other options:

  • Spinal cord (Option A): contributes to analgesia, but it is not the main site for ketamine’s anesthetic effect.
  • Hippocampus (Option B): is involved in memory formation, but is not the primary site for ketamine-induced dissociation.
  • Cerebellum (Option C): governs coordination and motor control, and ketamine’s effects are not primarily mediated here.

questions.text: Propofol infusion syndrome is associated with all except?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Propofol infusion syndrome (PRIS) is a rare but serious complication seen with prolonged, high-dose propofol infusions.
  • It is characterized by cardiac failure, bradycardia, metabolic acidosis, rhabdomyolysis, hyperlipidaemia, and renal failure. (Options A, B, C ruled out)
  • Electrolyte disturbances in PRIS typically include hyperkalaemia, not hypokalaemia, due to cellular breakdown and acidosis.

Key Takeaways:

  • PRIS includes cardiac, muscular, and metabolic complications, notably hyperkalaemia, not hypokalaemia.
  • Occurs with high-dose (>4 mg/kg/h) and prolonged infusions (>48 hours).
  • Early recognition and discontinuation of propofol are critical.

questions.text: Which intravenous induction agent may predispose to pancreatitis?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Propofol may predispose to pancreatitis, particularly with prolonged infusion or in patients with underlying hypertriglyceridemia.
  • Propofol is formulated in a lipid emulsion, and its use can cause elevated serum triglyceride levels, which are a known risk factor for acute pancreatitis.

Explanation of other options:
Etomidate (Option A): Known for adrenocortical suppression, not associated with pancreatitis.

Thiopentone (Option B): A barbiturate with no known link to pancreatic inflammation.

Ketamine (Option D): While it causes sympathetic stimulation, it is not implicated in causing pancreatitis.

Key Takeaways:

  • Propofol can cause hypertriglyceridemia, leading to pancreatitis.
  • Monitor lipid levels with prolonged infusions.
  • Other agents listed do not increase pancreatitis risk.

questions.text: Which of the following is associated with the maximum risk of life-threatening infections?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Propofol poses the maximum risk of life-threatening infections due to its lipid emulsion formulation, which serves as an excellent medium for bacterial and fungal growth. Strict aseptic precautions and limited duration of vial use (typically within 6–12 hours of opening) are required to prevent nosocomial infections and sepsis.

Explanation of other options:

  • Etomidate (Option B) is primarily associated with adrenocortical suppression, not increased infection risk.
  • Ketamine (Option C) has sympathomimetic and bronchodilatory effects, with no known risk of promoting infections.
  • Thiopentone (Option D) is a barbiturate with a long safety record in induction; it does not pose an elevated infection risk.

questions.text: Which of the following should not be used to reconstitute thiopentone?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Thiopentone is a strongly alkaline solution (pH ~10–11) and must be reconstituted only with compatible fluids to avoid precipitation or chemical interaction.
  • Ringer's lactate contains calcium, which can precipitate when mixed with thiopentone due to its high pH and potential for insoluble salt formation.
  • Glucose, though acidic, can still be used in emergency cases with caution, but is generally avoided due to the risk of precipitation (Option B ruled out).
  • Normal saline and sterile water are considered safe and compatible diluents for thiopentone reconstitution (Options C and D ruled out).

Key Takeaways:

  • Avoid Ringer's lactate for thiopentone due to precipitation risk with calcium.
  • Preferred diluents: normal saline and water.
  • Always check compatibility before IV drug mixing.

questions.text: Pain on injection is seen with all except?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Ketamine is water-soluble and has a neutral pH, which makes it least likely to cause pain on injection.
  • It is often well tolerated during IV administration, especially in pediatric and emergency settings.

Explanation of other options:
Propofol (Option A): Causes pain due to its lipid emulsion base and activation of the kinin cascade.

Etomidate (Option B): Formulated in propylene glycol, a known irritant, leading to frequent pain on injection.

Thiopentone (Option C): Its alkaline nature can irritate veins and cause discomfort during administration.

Key Takeaways:

  • Ketamine is the only IV agent listed that typically does not cause injection pain.
  • Pain with propofol, etomidate, and thiopentone is due to their formulations or pH.
  • Injection site comfort is an important consideration in anesthetic choice.

choices.text: Has been used to treat hypercortisolemia
To be avoided in neurosurgical procedures due to the risk of raised intracranial pressure

questions.text: Which of the following is a true statement concerning etomidate?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

Etomidate inhibits 11β-hydroxylase, a key enzyme in cortisol synthesis, leading to adrenocortical suppression. This pharmacologic effect has been therapeutically exploited in managing conditions like Cushing's syndrome, where reduction of endogenous cortisol is desired.

Contraindicated in coronary artery disease is incorrect; etomidate is cardiostable and does not significantly affect myocardial contractility or systemic vascular resistance, making it safe and preferred in patients with CAD (Option B ruled out).

Reduces postoperative nausea and vomiting is incorrect; in fact, etomidate is associated with a higher incidence of PONV, often requiring antiemetic prophylaxis (Option C ruled out).

To be avoided in neurosurgical procedures due to raised ICP is incorrect; etomidate reduces intracranial pressure and cerebral metabolic rate, making it suitable for neurosurgical induction, especially in patients with traumatic brain injury or increased ICP (Option D ruled out).

Key Takeaways:

  • Etomidate suppresses adrenal steroidogenesis and can be used in hypercortisolemia.
  • It is cardiostable, safe in CAD, and neuroprotective.
  • Known to cause PONV and myoclonus, but does not raise ICP.

questions.text: Which of the following anesthetics is associated with myoclonus during induction?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Etomidate is well known to cause myoclonus—sudden, brief, involuntary muscle jerks—especially during induction.
  • This effect is believed to be due to disinhibition of subcortical structures before cortical suppression fully sets in.
  • It occurs despite etomidate’s overall stable hemodynamic profile and is seen in up to 50–80% of cases without premedication.

Explanation of other options:
Propofol (Option A): Can cause muscle twitching, but true myoclonus is rare.

Thiopentone (Option C): Has anticonvulsant properties and is not associated with myoclonus.

Ketamine (Option D): Causes increased muscle tone or movements but not classic myoclonus.

Key Takeaways:

  • Etomidate is strongly associated with myoclonus during induction.
  • Premedication with benzodiazepines or opioids can reduce this risk.
  • Other IV agents do not commonly cause myoclonic activity.

questions.text: Which of the following intravenous anaesthetics raises Intracranial Pressure?
questions.solution:
Explanation for the answer:

  • Ketamine increases intracranial pressure (ICP) due to its cerebral vasodilation and elevation in cerebral blood flow. Ketamine is known to raise all pressures in the body—including ICP, intraocular pressure (IOP), and blood pressure—making it unsuitable in patients with raised ICP or neurosurgical conditions.
  • Thiopentone is a barbiturate commonly used for neuroprotection as it lowers ICP, reduces cerebral metabolic rate, and depresses cerebral electrical activity. It is typically used as a 5% solution, prepared from its sodium salt form mixed with 6% anhydrous sodium carbonate, reconstituted using sterile water, 5% dextrose, or normal saline.
  • Propofol and etomidate also decrease ICP, making them suitable for neuroanesthesia.

Explanation of other options:
Propofol (Choice A): Reduces cerebral blood flow and ICP; used in neurosurgical settings.

Thiopentone (Choice B): Lowers ICP; also provides anticonvulsant and neuroprotective effects.

Etomidate (Choice C): Causes minimal cardiovascular and respiratory depression while decreasing ICP.

Key Takeaways:

  • Ketamine raises ICP and should be avoided in neuro cases.
  • Thiopentone, propofol, and etomidate are preferred for patients with raised ICP.
  • Barbiturate preparations vary: thiopentone (2.5–5%), thiamylal (2%), methohexital (1%).

questions.text: Thiopentone is used in the induction of anaesthesia at a concentration of?
questions.solution:
Explanation for the answer:

  • Thiopentone is commonly used as a 2.5% solution for the induction of anesthesia. This concentration strikes a balance between effective hypnotic dosing and acceptable venous tolerability. The solution is prepared from thiopentone sodium, combined with 6% anhydrous sodium carbonate, and reconstituted with water, 5% dextrose, or normal saline.
  • The standard reconstituted concentrations for similar barbiturates include: thiamylal (2%) and methohexital (1%).

Key Takeaways:

  • Thiopentone is used as a 2.5% solution for induction.
  • Reconstituted using water, 5% glucose, or NS.
  • Other barbiturates: thiamylal (2%), methohexital (1%).

choices.text: Removal of the IV cannula from the artery
Dilution of the drug with saline

questions.text: Following an intra-arterial injection of thiopentone, all must be done except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Intra-arterial injection of thiopentone is a serious complication due to its alkaline pH (~10–11) and propensity to cause arterial spasm, thrombosis, and tissue necrosis.
  • Immediate removal of the IV cannula is contraindicated, as it eliminates access to deliver vasodilators, heparin, or flush solutions directly into the artery to mitigate damage.
  • Dilution with saline helps reduce local drug concentration and irritation. (Option B ruled out)
  • Heparinization prevents thrombus formation. (Option C ruled out)
  • Brachial plexus block promotes sympathetic blockade and vasodilation, improving arterial blood flow and reducing ischemic risk. (Option D ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • Do not remove the cannula after intra-arterial thiopentone injection.
  • Immediate steps include saline dilution, heparin, and regional block.
  • Early intervention is critical to prevent limb ischemia or necrosis.

questions.text: Which medication is often recommended to decrease the likelihood of coughing and laryngospasm due to ketamine-induced salivary secretions?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Ketamine stimulates salivary and tracheobronchial secretions, increasing the risk of laryngospasm and coughing during airway manipulation.
  • Glycopyrrolate, an anticholinergic agent, is often administered preoperatively to reduce secretions and minimize airway complications. It is preferred because it does not cross the blood-brain barrier, avoiding central anticholinergic side effects.

Explanation of other options:
Dopamine (Choice A): Not related to salivation; used as an inotropic agent.
Adrenaline (Choice B): A vasopressor and bronchodilator, but does not affect salivary secretions.
Neostigmine (Choice C): A cholinesterase inhibitor; would increase secretions, worsening the risk.

Key Takeaways:

  • Glycopyrrolate is the anticholinergic of choice to reduce ketamine-induced secretions.
  • Helps prevent laryngospasm and improves airway safety.
  • Other options do not mitigate secretions and are used for unrelated indications.

questions.text: Etomidate should be used carefully in?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Etomidate is hemodynamically stable and ideal for induction in patients with ischemic heart disease or hypertension due to minimal cardiovascular depression. However, it inhibits 11β-hydroxylase, leading to adrenocortical suppression, which impairs the body’s stress response—a critical concern in patients with shock, where cortisol production is essential for maintaining vascular tone and fluid balance.

Explanation of other options:
Patients with hypertension (Choice B): Etomidate causes minimal BP change; safe to use.
Patients with ischemic heart disease (Choice C): Preferred due to cardiac stability and minimal myocardial depression.

Key Takeaways:

  • Etomidate should be used cautiously in shock due to adrenal suppression.
  • Safe in hypertension and IHD due to cardiovascular neutrality.
  • Monitor adrenal function in critically ill patients.

questions.text: Effect of ketamine on CNS?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Ketamine causes cerebral vasodilation, leading to an increase in cerebral blood flow (CBF).
  • It raises intracranial pressure (ICP), especially in patients with impaired intracranial compliance.
  • Unlike most intravenous anesthetics, ketamine does not reduce cerebral metabolic rate of oxygen (CMRO2); it may increase it due to its CNS stimulant properties.
  • Therefore, none of the listed effects are true for ketamine’s impact on the CNS.

Key Takeaways:

  • Ketamine increases ICP, CBF, and possibly CMRO2.
  • It should be avoided in neurosurgical or raised ICP
  • Contrasts with other anesthetics that typically depress CNS activity.

choices.text: Produces profound analgesia at subanaesthetic doses

questions.text: Advantage of ketamine over propofol and etomidate, is?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Ketamine is unique among induction agents in that it provides strong analgesia even at subanesthetic doses, making it ideal for procedural sedation, burns dressing, and trauma cases.
  • Unlike propofol and etomidate, which lack significant analgesic properties, ketamine acts as an NMDA receptor antagonist, blocking central sensitization and pain transmission.
  • It does not require a lipid emulsion for formulation, unlike propofol, which is formulated in a lipid base and is associated with pain on injection and risk of infection.
  • Emergence delirium is a disadvantage of ketamine, often requiring benzodiazepine premedication to mitigate.

Explanation of other options:
It requires lipid emulsion (Option A): Ketamine is water-soluble; propofol requires lipid emulsion.
Produces emergence delirium (Option C): This is a disadvantage, not an advantage.

Key Takeaways:

  • Ketamine provides analgesia at subanesthetic doses, unlike other IV anesthetics.
  • It is water-soluble and does not require lipid emulsion.
  • Emergence reactions are a known limitation of ketamine.

questions.text: Content of etomidate that causes pain on injection?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Etomidate is formulated in propylene glycol, a hyperosmolar solvent used to dissolve the poorly water-soluble drug.
  • This formulation is known to cause pain on injection, due to its irritant nature to the vascular endothelium.
  • Some newer formulations use lipid emulsions to reduce this pain, similar to the approach with propofol.

Explanation of other options:
Methyl paraben (Option A): A preservative, not directly related to injection pain.
Imidazole ring (Option B): Part of the etomidate chemical structure but not responsible for injection pain.
Sodium citrate (Option C): Used as a buffering agent in other drugs; not relevant here.

Key Takeaways:

  • Propylene glycol in etomidate causes pain on IV injection.
  • Lipid-based formulations reduce this side effect.
  • Pain on injection is a known limitation of non-lipid etomidate.

questions.text: Drug of choice for the prevention of emergence delirium after ketamine?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Emergence delirium is a well-known side effect of ketamine, characterized by hallucinations, agitation, and vivid dreams during recovery.
  • Midazolam, a benzodiazepine, is the drug of choice to prevent this complication. It provides anxiolysis, sedation, and anterograde amnesia, effectively reducing the incidence and severity of ketamine-induced emergence reactions.
  • Midazolam is often given as a premedication before ketamine induction to preemptively manage these effects.

Explanation of other options:
Glycopyrrolate (Option B): Reduces salivary secretions but does not prevent the emergence of delirium.
Etomidate (Option C): Not used for sedation or managing emergence reactions.
Propofol (Option D): Induction agent with antiemetic properties but not the preferred agent for emergence delirium control.

Key Takeaways:

  • Midazolam is the DOC to prevent ketamine emergence delirium.
  • Premedication with benzodiazepines improves patient comfort postoperatively.
  • Other agents do not address the CNS excitatory effects of ketamine.

questions.text: Standout feature of etomidate for which it has been used?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Etomidate is especially valued in anesthesia for its cardiovascular stability during induction. It causes minimal changes in heart rate, stroke volume, and blood pressure, making it the induction agent of choice in hemodynamically unstable patients, including those with ischemic heart disease, trauma, or shock.
  • This standout feature distinguishes it from agents like propofol or thiopentone, which may cause significant hypotension during induction.

Explanation of other options:
CNS protection (Option B): Etomidate does reduce cerebral metabolic rate and ICP, but other agents like thiopentone are more commonly used for this purpose.
Excellent intubating conditions (Option C): Muscle relaxants primarily determine intubating conditions, not etomidate alone.
Renoprotection (Option D): Not a known or primary feature of etomidate.

Key Takeaways:

  • Etomidate’s hallmark is cardiovascular stability.
  • Ideal for induction in patients with cardiovascular compromise.
  • Not primarily used for CNS protection or renal effects.

questions.text: Effect of etomidate on the CNS?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Etomidate has favorable CNS effects, especially in neurosurgical settings. It acts as a direct cerebral vasoconstrictor, thereby reducing cerebral blood flow (CBF) and intracranial pressure (ICP) without compromising cerebral perfusion.
  • It also decreases the cerebral metabolic rate of oxygen consumption (CMRO2), contributing to neuroprotection.
  • Therefore, options A and C are incorrect, as etomidate neither increases CBF nor CMRO2. (Options A & C ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • Etomidate decreases CBF and CMRO2, making it ideal for neurosurgery.
  • Acts as a direct cerebral vasoconstrictor.
  • Does not increase ICP, unlike agents like ketamine.

questions.text: Use of ketamine is not advocated in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Ketamine is highly effective for painful procedures and emergency settings due to its analgesic, dissociative, and cardiovascular stimulant properties.
  • It is commonly used for induction in children, particularly in trauma or uncooperative cases, because it preserves airway reflexes and maintains hemodynamic stability.
  • For burn dressing changes and skin grafting, ketamine provides excellent procedural sedation and analgesia, especially in pediatric and hypovolemic patients.
  • Thus, all listed uses are appropriate, and there is no contraindication among them. (Options A, B, and C ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • Ketamine is safe and effective for pediatric induction and burn procedures.
  • Offers analgesia, amnesia, and cardiovascular support.
  • Not contraindicated in the listed situations.

choices.text: Depressant effects last for 6-8 hours after a single shot injection
Tidal volume decreases, but rate increases

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about the effects of etomidate on the respiratory system?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Etomidate is a relatively mild respiratory depressant compared to other induction agents like propofol or thiopentone.
  • After administration, it may cause a transient decrease in tidal volume, which is often compensated by an increase in respiratory rate, thereby maintaining minute ventilation.
  • The respiratory depressant effects are short-lived, usually resolving quickly due to its rapid redistribution, and do not persist for 6–8 hours following a single injection.

Explanation of other options:
Respiratory depressant (Option A): Correct—though mild, etomidate can cause some respiratory depression.
Tidal volume decreases but rate increases (Option C): Correct—reflects typical compensatory pattern post-induction.

Key Takeaways:

  • Etomidate causes mild and transient respiratory depression.
  • Effects resolve rapidly, not prolonged over hours.
  • Useful in patients needing cardiovascular stability with minimal respiratory compromise.

questions.text: Which is not a clinical effect of benzodiazepines?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Benzodiazepines exert multiple CNS effects, including anxiolysis, sedation (hypnosis), anticonvulsant activity, and muscle relaxation.
  • However, they do not possess intrinsic analgesic properties. They may reduce anxiety related to pain, but do not alleviate pain directly. This makes analgesia the only incorrect clinical effect in the list. (Option B ruled out)

Explanation of other options:
Anticonvulsant action (Option A): Correct—used in acute seizure management (e.g., diazepam, lorazepam).
Anxiolysis (Option C): Correct—primary use in premedication and anxiety disorders.
Hypnosis (Option D): Correct—induces sleep at higher doses, used in procedural sedation.

Key Takeaways:

  • Benzodiazepines lack a direct analgesic effect.
  • Commonly used for sedation, anxiolysis, and seizure control.
  • Do not substitute opioids or NSAIDs for pain management.

questions.text: The initial dose of Flumazenil is?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Flumazenil is a competitive benzodiazepine receptor antagonist used to reverse the sedative effects of benzodiazepines.
  • The initial recommended dose of flumazenil is 0.2 mg IV administered over 15 seconds.
  • If the desired level of consciousness is not achieved, it may be repeated every 60 seconds, up to a total cumulative dose of 1 mg.
  • This specific dosing allows for controlled reversal and reduces the risk of precipitating withdrawal or seizures in chronic benzodiazepine users.

Key Takeaways:

  • Flumazenil initial dose = 0.2 mg IV over 15 seconds.
  • Can be titrated every minute up to 1 mg total.
  • Used cautiously in patients with chronic benzodiazepine use or seizure disorders.

questions.text: As age increases, the half-life of Midazolam undergoes which of the following changes?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Midazolam, a short-acting benzodiazepine, undergoes hepatic metabolism via cytochrome P450 enzymes.
  • In elderly patients, there is a reduction in hepatic blood flow and metabolic capacity, which slows clearance of the drug.
  • Consequently, the elimination half-life of midazolam is increased in the elderly compared to younger adults, leading to prolonged sedation and delayed recovery. (Option A retained)

Explanation of other options:
Decreased (Option B): Incorrect—clearance is reduced in the elderly, not increased.
Same (Option C): Incorrect—pharmacokinetic changes with aging alter drug metabolism.
None of the above (Option D): Incorrect—there is a definitive increase in half-life.

Key Takeaways:

  • Midazolam's half-life increases with age due to decreased hepatic metabolism.
  • Use lower doses in the elderly to prevent excessive sedation.
  • Careful monitoring is essential to avoid respiratory depression.

questions.text: Which of the following is a side effect of dexmedetomidine?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Dexmedetomidine is a selective alpha-2 adrenergic agonist used for sedation, especially in ICU and procedural settings.
  • It causes central sympatholysis, leading to bradycardia and hypotension, which are its most commonly reported side effects.
  • Unlike many other sedatives, it produces minimal respiratory depression, making it favorable for conscious sedation. (Option A ruled out)
  • It has antiemetic rather than emetogenic properties. (Option B ruled out)
  • It also provides moderate analgesia, especially in combination with other agents. (Option D ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • Dexmedetomidine commonly causes bradycardia and hypotension.
  • Minimal respiratory depression, even at higher doses.
  • Provides sedation with analgesia, reducing the need for opioids.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a clinical use of Midazolam?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Midazolam, a short-acting benzodiazepine, is commonly used for premedication, sedation, and induction/maintenance of anesthesia due to its anxiolytic, amnestic, and sedative effects.
  • It is not an analgesic and does not provide pain relief, hence not used for postoperative analgesia. (Option A ruled out)
  • It is frequently employed for postoperative sedation in ventilated patients. (Option C retained)
  • Its role in premedication and maintenance of anesthesia is well-established, especially in combination with other agents.

Key Takeaways:

  • Midazolam lacks analgesic properties.
  • Commonly used for sedation, premedication, and anesthesia maintenance.
  • Should be combined with analgesics for pain control.

choices.text: Metabolised by the cytochrome P450 microsomal enzyme system
Metabolites produced are 1 1-hydroxy midazolam and 4 4-hydroxy midazolam
4 h4-hydroxymidazolam is present in significant amounts in plasma

questions.text: Which of the following is false about Midazolam?
questions.solution:
Explanation :

  • 4-hydroxy midazolam is a minor metabolite of midazolam and is not found in significant concentrations in plasma, making this statement incorrect.
  • Midazolam is metabolized primarily by the cytochrome P450 (CYP3A4) enzyme system.
  • The major metabolites are 1-hydroxymidazolam (which is active) and 4-hydroxy midazolam (minor).
  • 1-hydroxymidazolam contributes to pharmacologic effects, especially in patients with renal impairment.
    (Option C ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • Midazolam metabolism involves CYP3A4 enzymes. (Option A ruled out)
  • 1-hydroxymidazolam is active and clinically significant. (Option D ruled out)
  • 4-hydroxy midazolam is present in negligible amounts.(Option B ruled out)

questions.text: Clinical effects of Dexmedetomidine are all except?
questions.solution:
Explanation :

  • Dexmedetomidine is a highly selective alpha-2 adrenergic agonist, and its primary action is sympatholytic, not sympathomimetic—meaning it reduces sympathetic outflow, leading to bradycardia and hypotension. (Option A)
  • It has sedative and hypnotic properties due to action on the locus coeruleus, promoting natural sleep-like sedation.
  • It also has mild analgesic effects, making it useful in ICU sedation and perioperative settings without causing respiratory depression.

Key Takeaways:

  • Dexmedetomidine is sympatholytic, not sympathomimetic.
  • Provides sedation, hypnosis, and analgesia. (Choice B & D ruled out)
  • Used for conscious sedation and ICU sedation without respiratory depression. (Choice C ruled out)

questions.text: Which of the following is a competitive inhibitor of benzodiazepines?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Flumazenil is a specific competitive antagonist at benzodiazepine binding sites on the GABA-A receptor. It is used to reverse the sedative and hypnotic effects of benzodiazepines in overdose or procedural sedation.
  • It has a rapid onset and short duration, requiring careful titration to avoid resedation or withdrawal seizures in chronic benzodiazepine users.
    (Option C ruled out)

Explanation of other options:
Disulfiram (Option A): Used in alcohol dependence by inhibiting aldehyde dehydrogenase.
Flunarizine (Option B): A calcium channel blocker used in migraine prophylaxis.
Naloxone (Option D): An opioid antagonist, not effective against benzodiazepines.

Key Takeaways:

  • Flumazenil is the antidote for benzodiazepine overdose.
  • Acts on GABA-A receptors.
  • Requires cautious use due to short half-life and risk of seizures.

choices.text: Apnoea after a large dose of midazolam is sustained and prolonged

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with no significant past medical history is brought to the endoscopy suite for an elective colonoscopy. He is anxious, and the physician administers intravenous midazolam in 2-mg increments to a total of 6 mg to achieve conscious sedation. Five minutes later, his respiratory rate decreases from 16 breaths/min to 8 breaths/min, and the pulse oximeter shows an SpO2 of 90% on room air. Which of the following best describes the effect of midazolam on the respiratory system?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Midazolam, like other benzodiazepines, causes dose-dependent depression of the central respiratory drive, especially the hypoxic drive, making Option A correct.
  • In high doses or when combined with other CNS depressants (e.g., opioids), it may cause apnea, but this is typically short-lived and not sustained or prolonged as stated in Option B. (Option B ruled out)
  • The respiratory depressant effects are dose-dependent, contrary to Option C. (Option C ruled out)
  • Airway reflexes are blunted with sedative doses, especially when combined with other depressants, so Option D is also incorrect. (Option D ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • Midazolam depresses the hypoxic respiratory drive.
  • Effects on respiration are dose-dependent.
  • Airway reflexes are not preserved reliably.

choices.text: Bind to the gamma subunit of the GABA receptor

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding benzodiazepines?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Benzodiazepines enhance the effect of GABA (gamma-aminobutyric acid) by increasing the frequency of chloride channel opening at GABA-A receptors, thereby producing sedation, anxiolysis, muscle relaxation, and anticonvulsant effects. They are GABA facilitators, not direct agonists.
  • They bind to the alpha and gamma interface of the GABA-A receptor, not specifically to the gamma subunit alone as stated in Option B. (Option B ruled out)
  • They are not GABA mimetics; they require endogenous GABA to exert their effects, unlike barbiturates, which have some GABA mimetic activity. (Option C ruled out)
  • GABA-B receptors are G-protein coupled and are not the target of benzodiazepines. (Option D ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • Benzodiazepines are GABA-A facilitators, not mimetics.
  • Bind at the alpha-gamma interface, not directly to GABA-B receptors.
  • Require GABA for action.

questions.text: Features of Propofol infusion syndrome are all except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Propofol infusion syndrome (PRIS) is a rare but potentially fatal complication associated with prolonged, high-dose propofol use, especially in critically ill patients.
  • It typically presents with bradycardia, rhabdomyolysis, metabolic (lactic) acidosis, hyperlipidemia, and cardiac failure. (Option A ruled out)
  • Green discoloration of urine is a recognized benign side effect of propofol metabolism.
  • Rhabdomyolysis and lactic acidosis are serious systemic manifestations of mitochondrial dysfunction caused by PRIS.

Key Takeaways:

  • PRIS presents with bradycardia, rhabdomyolysis, and lactic acidosis. (Choice B & D ruled out)
  • Tachycardia is not a typical feature—in fact, bradycardia is common.
  • Green urine may occur due to phenol metabolites of propofol. (Choice C)

choices.text: In the ICU, to induce barbiturate coma

questions.text: Which of the following are the clinical uses of thiopentone except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Thiopentone is primarily used for the induction of anesthesia due to its rapid onset and short duration of action.
  • It is not suitable for maintenance of anesthesia because of its long context-sensitive half-life and accumulation in body fat, leading to prolonged sedation. (Option C ruled out)
  • It is used in neuroprotection, such as in status epilepticus, and to induce barbiturate coma in ICU settings due to its cerebral metabolic suppression and reduction in ICP.

Key Takeaways:

  • Thiopentone is not used for maintenance due to the risk of accumulation and prolonged recovery.
  • It is effective for induction, status epilepticus, and barbiturate coma in the ICU. (Choice A, B, D)

choices.text: Reconstituted with water to form a 10% solution
Available as a pale, hygroscopic yellow powder
It is suspended in an atmosphere of nitrogen
Contains 500 mg or 1000 mg per vial

questions.text: Which of the following regarding thiopentone is false?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Thiopentone is typically reconstituted to form a 2.5% solution for the induction of anesthesia. A 10% solution is too concentrated and increases the risk of venous irritation and complications.
  • It is supplied as a pale yellow hygroscopic powder, stabilized with anhydrous sodium carbonate, and is stored in nitrogen to prevent degradation from atmospheric CO2.
  • Commercial preparations typically come in 500 mg or 1000 mg vials, which are then reconstituted as needed.

Key Takeaways:

  • Thiopentone is reconstituted to 2.5%, not 10%, for clinical use.
  • Stored as hygroscopic powder under nitrogen. (Option B & C ruled out)
  • Available in 500 mg/1000 mg vials. (Option D ruled out)

choices.text: Diluting the drug to make it less concentrated

questions.text: Pain on injection associated with Propofol can be reduced by all except?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Pain on injection is a well-known side effect of propofol, attributed to its aqueous phase interacting with free nerve endings in the vein wall.
  • Mixing with lignocaine, diluting the drug, and injecting into a large vein (like the antecubital fossa) are all evidence-based methods to reduce this pain. (Option A ruled out)
  • While some newer formulations with modified lipid carriers have attempted to reduce pain, changing lipid composition alone is not a reliable or widely used method, hence not a consistent or standard preventive measure.

Key Takeaways:

  • Pain on propofol injection is common but can be minimized.
  • Lignocaine, dilution, and large vein injection are effective methods. (Option C & D ruled out)
  • Changing lipid composition is not a standard or consistently effective solution.

questions.text: Pathophysiology of gangrene due to intra-arterial injection of thiopentone is?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Thiopentone, when accidentally injected into an artery, causes intense arterial vasospasm due to its alkaline pH and irritant properties, leading to ischemia and gangrene of the distal limb.
  • This is a vascular phenomenon, not primarily neurogenic, and it does not stem from infection or venous spasm, as the arterial route is involved.
  • Prompt management includes heparinization, brachial plexus block, and measures to dilate the artery and reduce thrombosis. (Options A, C, D ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • Arterial vasospasm is the main cause of gangrene following intra-arterial thiopentone injection.
  • Requires urgent intervention to preserve limb viability.
  • Not caused by neurogenic, venous, or infectious mechanisms.

questions.text: The dose of Propofol at which lactic acidosis develops is?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Propofol infusion syndrome (PRIS) is associated with high-dose propofol infusion, especially when rates ≥1 mg/kg/min are maintained for prolonged periods (>48 hours), particularly in critically ill or pediatric patients.
  • At or above this dosage, mitochondrial dysfunction and impaired fatty acid oxidation may lead to lactic acidosis, cardiac failure, rhabdomyolysis, and other systemic effects.
  • Lower doses like 5 or 0.75 mg/kg/min are generally considered safer, while 2 mg/kg/min significantly increases the risk and is not routinely used for prolonged sedation. (Options A, B, D ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • PRIS risk begins at ≥1 mg/kg/min infusion.
  • Monitor for metabolic acidosis and cardiac issues at higher doses.
  • Use the lowest effective dose for the shortest duration.

choices.text: High amplitude slow frequency waves with burst suppression
High amplitude slow frequency waves without burst suppression
Low amplitude, high frequency waves with burst suppression
Low amplitude, high frequency waves without burst suppression

questions.text: EEG changes seen with thiopentone are?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Thiopentone, a barbiturate, causes dose-dependent depression of EEG activity.
  • At high doses, it induces a pattern of high amplitude slow frequency waves with burst suppression, which is a desired effect during barbiturate coma or neuroprotection in refractory intracranial hypertension or status epilepticus.
  • The burst suppression pattern indicates cerebral metabolic suppression and reduced electrical activity. (Options B, C, D ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • Thiopentone leads to burst suppression at high doses.
  • EEG shows high amplitude slow waves, helpful for neuroprotection.
  • Used in status epilepticus, raised ICP, and barbiturate coma.

questions.text: In which of the following cases is Thiopentone contraindicated?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Thiopentone is contraindicated in acute intermittent porphyria (AIP) due to its potent induction of hepatic ALA synthase, the rate-limiting enzyme in the heme biosynthesis pathway. This enzymatic activation can precipitate an acute porphyric attack with symptoms like abdominal pain, neuropsychiatric manifestations, and autonomic instability.
  • Conditions like sideroblastic anemia, phenylketonuria, and maple syrup urine disease do not involve the porphyrin pathway and are not exacerbated by barbiturates, though general caution with sedative agents is always warranted. (Options A, B, C ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • Thiopentone is contraindicated in AIP due to the risk of porphyric crisis.
  • Safer alternatives like propofol should be used in porphyric patients.
  • Always evaluate metabolic disorders for drug interactions with enzyme-inducing agents.

choices.text: A standard adult induction dose is safe due to preserved hepatic metabolism in the elderly.
Propofol enhances airway reflexes and must be avoided when using laryngeal mask airways.
A lower induction dose should be used due to altered pharmacokinetics and increased sensitivity.
It is contraindicated in patients with a history of egg allergy due to its lipid formulation.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man with no significant comorbidities is scheduled for outpatient cataract surgery. The anesthesiologist plans to induce general anesthesia with intravenous Propofol. Regarding the use of Propofol in this elderly patient, which of the following statements is most accurate?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:

A lower induction dose of Propofol should be used in elderly patients due to altered pharmacokinetics and increased sensitivity. Elderly patients exhibit a reduced central compartment volume, decreased clearance, and an enhanced pharmacodynamic effect of Propofol. This means that a smaller amount of the drug will achieve the desired effect and remain in the body longer, necessitating a reduction in the standard adult induction dose by approximately 25-50% to prevent excessive sedation or hemodynamic depression.

  • Pharmacokinetic Changes: Elderly patients generally have a smaller volume of distribution for lipid-soluble drugs like Propofol, less efficient drug metabolism and excretion (reduced clearance), and a reduced lean body mass.
  • Pharmacodynamic Sensitivity: They also exhibit increased brain sensitivity to anesthetic agents, leading to a more pronounced effect at a given plasma concentration.
  • Propofol typically causes increased latency and decreased amplitude of cortical auditory evoked potentials.
  • Clinical Implication: These factors collectively necessitate a lower induction dose to ensure a safe and effective anesthetic induction while minimizing adverse effects like hypotension and prolonged recovery.
  • Aquavan is a water-soluble prodrug of propofol developed to reduce the side effects of lipid-based formulations, such as pain on injection, infection risk, and hypertriglyceridemia. It is converted to active propofol by endothelial alkaline phosphatases.

Explanation of Other Options:

A standard adult induction dose is safe due to preserved hepatic metabolism in the elderly (Option A). This statement is incorrect. While some hepatic function may be preserved, the overall pharmacokinetic profile of Propofol is significantly altered in the elderly, primarily due to decreased clearance and a reduced central compartment volume, leading to increased sensitivity, making a standard dose unsafe.

Propofol enhances airway reflexes and must be avoided when using laryngeal mask airways(Option B): This statement is incorrect. Propofol is well-known for its ability to suppress airway and laryngeal reflexes, making it highly suitable for use with laryngeal mask airways (LMAs). It does not irritate the airway, which is an advantage for airway instrumentation.

It is contraindicated in patients with a history of egg allergy due to its lipid formulation(Option D). This statement is incorrect as an absolute contraindication in all cases of egg allergy. Propofol is formulated in an emulsion containing soybean oil, glycerol, and purified egg phosphatide. While there is a very low risk of reaction in patients with a history of anaphylaxis to egg products, routine egg allergy is generally not considered an absolute contraindication according to current guidelines.

Key Takeaway:

In elderly patients, Propofol induction doses must be reduced (by 25-50%) due to altered pharmacokinetics (reduced central compartment, decreased clearance) and increased sensitivity. Propofol suppresses airway reflexes, making it suitable for LMAs, and while containing egg phosphatide, routine egg allergy is not an absolute contraindication. Its CNS effects include increased latency and decreased amplitude of evoked potentials.

choices.text: Does not produce pain on IV injection

questions.text: True about midazolam as an inducing agent
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The statement that Midazolam does not produce pain on IV injection is true, making it the correct option. Midazolam is a unique benzodiazepine because it is formulated as a water-soluble preparation at a low pH, which makes its intravenous injection generally painless and reliable, unlike other benzodiazepines like diazepam, which are lipid-soluble and can cause pain or unreliable absorption upon injection.

  • Water-soluble formulation: Midazolam's water solubility at a low pH ensures it is in an ionized form in the vial, preventing precipitation and making its intravenous administration smooth and painless.
  • Rapid onset and short duration: While not as rapid as propofol or thiopental, Midazolam has a relatively quick onset of action and a shorter elimination half-life (2-3 hours), making it suitable for induction, especially in day-care procedures, and its effects can be reversed with flumazenil.
  • Other effects: Midazolam provides anterograde amnesia, muscle relaxation (at the spinal level), and is effective in preventing and controlling seizures.

Explanation of Other Options:

Increase in BP (Option A): This statement is incorrect. Midazolam, as an inducing agent, typically causes a decrease in blood pressure (BP). It has a notable cardiovascular depressant effect, contributing to a reduction in cardiac output.
